Judul: Ethical Tensions in Prison Art  Education
Abstrak:
This essay urges artists who teach in jails and prisons to reflect on the ethics and 
responsibilities of working with incarcerated people, creating artwork, and engaging 
social justice issues. It draws on recent controversies surrounding artists who make 
artworks that address political issues but are perceived by some to be appropriating 
the suffering of others for personal gain. Teaching artists, the essay suggests, may 
want to give priority to their incarcerated students, refrain from making work that 
claims to represent those who are incarcerated, and instead focus their artwork on 
the ways in which their own experiences of teaching in prisons have transformed 
them personally.
